articles.description:
Posted by Suzanne Frey, VP, Product, Android & Play Security and Privacy

We introduced Android‚Äôs Private Compute Core in Android 12 Beta. Today, we're excited to announce a new suite of services that provide a privacy-preserving bridge between Private Compute Core and the cloud.   
Recap: What is Private Compute Core? 
Android‚Äôs Private Compute Core is an open source, secure environment that is isolated from the rest of the operating system and apps. With each new Android release we‚Äôll add more privacy-pre‚Ä¶
articles.title: Introducing Android‚Äôs Private Compute Services

articles.description:
Posted by Eric Brewer and Dan Lorenc


Yesterday, we were honored to participate in President Biden‚Äôs White House Cyber Security Summit where we shared recommendations to advance the administration‚Äôs cybersecurity agenda. This included our commitment to invest $10 billion over the next five years to expand zero-trust programs, help secure the software supply chain, and enhance open-source security.
At Google, we‚Äôve long advocated for securing the software supply chain both through our internal best practice‚Ä¶
articles.title: Updates on our continued collaboration with NIST to secure the Software Supply Chain

articles.description:
On this special edition of The Changelog, we‚Äôre talking with Cory Wilkerson, Senior Director of Engineering at GitHub, about GitHub Codespaces. For years now, the possibility of coding in the cloud seemed so close, yet so far away for a number of reasons. According to Cory, the raw ingredients to make coding in the cloud a reality have been there for years. The challenge has really been how the industry thinks, and we are now at a place where the skepticism in cloud based workflows is ‚Äúnon-existent.‚Äù
After ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 459: Coding in the cloud with Codespaces

articles.description:
Migrating off jQuery? So was Sachin Neravath:
Most of the projects use only 15% to 20% or less than 30% of the jquery methods And in most of the cases, I didn‚Äôt want to support all the edge cases or legacy browsers. The hardest part was finding the jQuery methods in the existing project and writing the alternative vanilla js methods without making much changes in the codebase. So I wrote this library which automatically finds jquery methods in any particular JavaScript file and generates readable, chainable‚Ä¶
articles.title: Auto-generate vanilla JS alternatives for jQuery methods

articles.description:
Amazon EKS Anywhere is a new deployment option for Amazon EKS that enables you to easily create and operate Kubernetes clusters on-premises with your own virtual machines. It brings a consistent AWS management experience to your data center, building on the strengths of Amazon EKS Distro, the same distribution of Kubernetes that powers EKS on AWS. Its goal is to include full lifecycle management of multiple Kubernetes clusters that are capable of operating completely independently of any AWS services.
Discu‚Ä¶
articles.title: You can now run Amazon EKS on your own infra

David Flanagan, a.k.a. Rawkode, needs no introduction. Some of you may remember Marques Johansson from The new changelog.com setup for 2019. Marques was behind the Linode Terraforming that we used at the time, and our infrastructure was simpler because of it!

In this episode, Ian and sam join Johnny and Kris to discuss how to build actually maintainable software, the features of Go that make it good for writing maintainable software, and different ways that we might define the term ‚Äúmaintenance‚Äù.

articles.description:
You gently face-palm and let out a groan. Your bug is so obvious now. How did you miss it before? Thank goodness you didn‚Äôt blame Bob publicly.
In this blog post we will look at how to get unstuck with things you do not understand (yet). It‚Äôs a methodical approach to solving insight problems - problems where all the information is known but you need to see it a different light to solve it. We start from writing down the problem and move through increasingly more esoteric phases such as changing location to ‚Ä¶
articles.title: I don't understand this (yet)

articles.description:
Should you use small or large instances in a Kubernetes cluster? It depends. You should consider a few factors when selecting an instance type:
What kind of workloads you deploy (i.e. memory and CPU requirements).
The blast radius you can tolerate.
How you design your HA strategy.
How many resources are available to the pods.
This calculator helps you select what‚Äôs right from over 700 instances from the major cloud providers.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Kubernetes instance calculator

articles.description:
Emma Hyde:
I have seen a staggering amount of Ruby is Dead missives in the last few years, and a decline, or at least, an often discussed decline, of the language‚Äôs popularity and ranking. But what makes Ruby so much worse than other languages?
She goes on to discuss how Ruby 3.0 addresses two of the most criticized elements of Ruby: its ability to handle processes simultaneously and and its overall performance.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Ruby is still a diamond

articles.description:
This is a ~15 minute presentation (with transcript) by √Ålvaro Hern√°ndez at a Data on Kubernetes Community event about why he believes Kubernetes solves a big problem with running Postgres in production.
Running a Postgres installation, with or without containers, is trivial. However, setting up a production environment is a whole different matter. Postgres is not by itself a production-ready software: it requires a set of side tools to complement its functionality: connection pooling, monitoring, backup too‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why you should be deploying Postgres primarily on Kubernetes

A wise, mature person would treat the software engineer interview process as a pure learning experience. He, or she, would enjoy learning about companies out there fo‚Ä¶

There‚Äôs however a project that can solve this. Its name is sigstore and in this article we will look at what ‚Ä¶

What Vercel has enabled teams to do with Next.js is next level, and it‚Äôs truly evident when you read stories like this one from Cory Etzkorn on Notion migrating their marketing site to Next.js.
We rebuilt our entire marketing site from scratch, choosing to go with a statically generated architecture over our former purely client-rendered approach. Two months and 109 React components later, we‚Äôve now fully migrated to our framework of choice, Next.js, and couldn‚Äôt be happier with our decision. Here‚Äôs how we ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Ain was born out of the frustration of working with many API endpoints in GUI clients.
While pretty, I could‚Äôt use any shell-scripts or commands such as uuidgen as input to the endpoints without copy pasting from a terminal. And I had to copy-paste the resulting output back into the terminal to further slice and dice it.
I had become a human pipe and my ctrl+c, ctrl+v fingers were hurting. By using curl and/or httpie for the heavy lifting, Ain removes you from the piping of input and output. With Ain, you c‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ain is a terminal API client (alternative to Postman, Paw, Insomnia)

articles.description:
Here‚Äôs their pitch:
Do you have a home server you want to run a few apps on, but don‚Äôt want everything to
Do you have a work server that you want to run a few small services on, but don‚Äôt want
Harbormaster is for you.
You create a YAML config file with all the git repos you want it to include and it‚Äôll watch them for changes (on a timer) and do the necessary cloning/pulling, service restarting, etc. that needs doing to make it all run. Simple. Neat!
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Harbormaster ‚Äì¬†easily deploy many Docker-Compose apps on a single host

From Niels Leenheer:
It is not difficult to find some incredibly shitty takes on Electron, and every time it boils down to: It‚Äôs slow. Downloads are huge, and it uses a lot of memory. Electron apps are just websites. Developers that are using Electron are taking the lazy or easy approach to cross-platform development. Native apps are just better in every single way.
And somehow, these arguments often come from Apple fans when they discover one of their apps isn‚Äôt ‚Äúnative‚Äù or when a macOS favourite is consid‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why Electron apps are fine

articles.description:
Big news from Deno today.
Today we are releasing Deploy Beta 2. This is the second in a series of beta releases that will be made over the coming months. Each release will add features and refine the programming model. The releases will culminate in a General Availability announcement that we estimate will happen in Q4 2021.
Over the past eight months, we have been quietly designing this hosted service to supplement workflows with the open source Deno CLI. Deploy does not run on AWS Lambda nor does it use C‚Ä¶
articles.title: Deno Deploy Beta 2

articles.description:
Routing might be implemented in a number of ways: it‚Äôs sometimes code running on a server that maps a path to files on disk, or logic in a single-page app that waits for changes to the current location and creates a corresponding piece of DOM to display.
Buggy routing (and breaking your browser‚Äôs Back button) has been the achilles heel of SPAs since forver. Hopefully better tooling like this URLPattern proposal will help developers better handle the need.
I like what I see from the linked write-up. The feat‚Ä¶
articles.title: URLPattern brings routing to the web platform

Docs play an essential role in GitHub Actions, and Gerhard‚Äôs experience has proven that. Building, testing, and shipping code with GitHub Actions works better because of their excellent docs. However, the docs that Kathy pictures are not what you are imagining. She explains it best in her post, Maybe it‚Äôs time we re-think docs, which is what started this whole conversati‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Yes, to all of this! Dave Bailey, author of The Founder Coach, shared ten useful patterns to help nurture more generous interpretations of others‚Äô behaviors.
Reading this makes me really miss producing Brain Science.
When we encounter emotions and behaviours that don‚Äôt make sense to us, it‚Äôs often because we don‚Äôt have all the information. And in the absence of information, we tend to assume the worst.
‚ÄòEmotional generosity‚Äô is the ability to see past behaviours that we don‚Äôt understand and proactively look‚Ä¶

Peter also tells us a bit about the exciting new partnership between Anaconda and Pyston (a fork of the standard CPython interpreter which has been extensively enhanced to improve the execution performance of most Python programs).

We started our GraphQL adoption journey by building our checkout experience. We saw tremendous benefits in adopting GraphQL when our checkout app built with GraphQL became our guiding light.We built more apps, provided infrastructure support, launched a public GraphQL API, and provided trainings and learning materials across the company. We also set up a standards body, provided a GraphQL tools fanny pack, and built sample apps to help teams get started.

TJ tells us why Neovim was created in the first place, how it differs from Vim, why Lua is awesome for configuration and plugins, what LSPs are all about, the cool tech inside tree-sitter, and how he‚Äôs writing his own fuzzy file finder for Neovim called Telescope.

articles.description:
Jina calls itself a ‚Äúcloud-native neural search framework‚Äù. What is neural search, exactly?
The core idea of neural search is to leverage state-of-the-art deep neural networks to build every component of a search system. In short, neural search is deep neural network-powered information retrieval. In academia, it‚Äôs often called neural IR.
And what can it do for you?
Thanks to recent advances in deep neural networks, a neural search system can go way beyond simple text search. It enables advanced intelligenc‚Ä¶
articles.title: Jina ‚Äì¬†build search-as-a-service powered by deep learning in just minutes

From Axios:
Apple said Thursday it will relax some App Store rules in order to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by U.S.-based developers over its store terms.
‚Ä¶Apple will let developers communicate with users about alternative payment methods outside of the App Store. It will also set up a $100 million fund for small developers and make some other changes to its practices, but it‚Äôs keeping its overall commission structure.
This settlement is not yet approved by Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers.

articles.description:
From Den Delimarsky:
We are truly living in an era of user-hostile software, and when I say ‚Äúuser-hostile‚Äù I mean it as ‚Äúsoftware that doesn‚Äôt really care about the needs of the user but rather about the needs of the developer.‚Äù And this is not a problem that is bound to a specific operating system (or version thereof) or class or computers. It‚Äôs literally cross-platform, and it follows customers from home, to office, to their commute.
Let me give you some examples from my own experience‚Ä¶
A common offender ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
This comment on HN does a great job summarizing Bashly.
‚Ä¶think of this as an argparse equivalent for Bash. You provide a YAML file listing commands, subcommands, arguments, and flags, and it automatically generates a Bash script that can parse and validate them, provide help messages, and run your code for each command.
It also lets you keep the actual code for each command and subcommand in separate files, which are merged together into one distributable Bash script at generation time. It‚Äôs basically a tem‚Ä¶
articles.title: Bashly - Bash CLI Framework and Generator

articles.description:
Thank you for sharing this Maya. These pull-quotes resonated with me.
I don‚Äôt think I noticed I was burnt out until early February 2021, almost six months later. Honestly, realizing it was kind of a relief. I hadn‚Äôt noticed how bad it had gotten. A few weeks later, I quit my job. And then a new, different kind of struggle started. Not knowing what to do with myself, or how to recover.
So why did I burn out? I don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs not a single thing - like a specific work stressor - that caused my burnout. It wa‚Ä¶
articles.title: Burning out and quitting

For some of you listening you might remember John‚Äôs appearance on The Changelog #11, which was basically forever ago. Or his company Ordered List ‚Äî they made Gauges, Harmony, and Speaker Deck which was quite popular in its time ‚Äî so much so that they attracted the attention of Chris Wanstrath, one of the co-founders of GitHub to acquire Ordered List. The rest as they say is history. Today, John and I go back through that history to see what i‚Ä¶

Codex is a descendant of GPT-3 ‚Äì its training data contains both natural language and billions of lines of source code from publicly available sources, including code in public GitHub repositories.
‚ÄúWe see this as a tool to multiply programmers,‚Äù OpenAI‚Äôs CTO and co-founder Greg Brockman told The Verge. ‚ÄúProgramming has two parts to it: you have ‚Äòthink hard about a problem and try to understand it,‚Äô and ‚Äòmap those small pieces to existing code, whether it‚Äôs a library, a function, or an API.‚Äô‚Äù The second par‚Ä¶

Redis is awesome, but Redis commands are not always fun. Pottery is a Pythonic way to access Redis. If you know how to use Python dicts, then you already know how to use Pottery. Pottery is useful for accessing Redis more easily, and also for implementing microservice resilience patterns; and it has been battle tested in production at scale.

In this episode, Gerhard follows up on The Changelog #375, which is the last time that he spoke Crossplane with Dan and Jared. Many things changed since then, such as abstractions and compositions, as well as using Crossplane to build platforms, which were mostly ideas.
Fast forward 18 months, 2k changes, as well as a major version, and Crossplane is now an easy choice - some would say the best choice - for platform teams to declare what infrastructure means to them. You can now use Crossplane to define you‚Ä¶

With the help of many great tools, we‚Äôve successfully built a fast, collaborative todo app. More importantly, we‚Äôve worked out a reasonably simple approach to building similar web apps. As the user base and feature set grow, this approach shall scale well in both performance and complexity.
Both the res‚Ä¶
articles.title: A simple way to build collaborative web apps

articles.description:
There was a glorious (albeit too short) period on the web when we were mashing up APIs from various startups and tech companies to create cool stuff. Then things changed. The web grew up, became Serious Business‚Ñ¢Ô∏è, and free/public APIs got harder and harder to find. Turns out, there‚Äôs still a bunch of good ones out there!
This repo has collected them in one long, categorized list for us to reference. üëè
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A collection of free/public APIs you can use to build awesome stuff

articles.description:
PlayCover lets you sideload iOS apps and games onto your Mac and run them like any other app. Simply drag-n-drop the .ipa file and wait for PlayCover to convert and launch the app. Here‚Äôs a video of it in action playing Genshin Impact.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Run iOS apps on your M1 Mac with mouse, keyboard, and controller support

articles.description:
Sherloq is a personal research project about implementing a fully integrated environment for digital image forensics. It is not meant as an automatic tool that decide if an image is forged or not (that tool probably will never exist‚Ä¶), but as a companion in experimenting with various algorithms found in the latest research papers and workshops.
The original version was written in C++ in 2015, but a port to Python is in the works. It looks super useful, but buyer beware:
I‚Äôm happy to share my code and get in‚Ä¶
articles.title: A digital image forensic toolset

articles.description:
In Kenya, 33% of maternal deaths are caused by delays in seeking care, and 55% of maternal deaths are caused by delays in action or inadequate care by providers. Jacaranda Health is employing NLP and dialogue system techniques to help mothers experience childbirth safely and with respect and to help newborns get a safe start in life. Jay and Sathy from Jacaranda join us in this episode to discuss how they are using AI to prioritize incoming SMS messages from mothers and help them get the care they need.
Dis‚Ä¶
articles.title: Practical AI 145: NLP to help pregnant mothers in Kenya

articles.description:
Brett Cannon:
‚Ä¶ over 3 years ago I set out to re-implement the Python Launcher for Unix in Rust. On July 24, 2021, I launched 1.0.0 of the Python Launcher for Unix‚Ä¶ This gives you a py command on Unix which will always use the newest version of Python.
He goes on to describe some workflow niceties that a built in and also what this project is not about:
The Launcher is purely a convenience and not meant to be The Launcher For All Things; this should never end up in a Docker container.
Discuss on Changelog N‚Ä¶
articles.title: Introducing the Python launcher for  Unix

articles.description:
Matt Rickard shares 31 reflections after putting his time 10k hours in programming:
These are reflections only about pure coding ‚Äî no lessons sum up to ‚Äúprogramming is about people‚Äù or ‚Äúhow to be a senior technical leader‚Äù (arguably more important to a career, but not the topic of this post).
These reflections are just about deliberately writing code for 10,000 hours. Most don‚Äôt apply to beginners. These reflections are not career advice. Think of them as lessons on being a technical guitarist, not about be‚Ä¶
articles.title: Reflections on 10,000 hours of programming

articles.description:
Ned Batchelder, after reading some code to termine whether or not it was ‚ÄúPythonic‚Äù:
My first response was that I don‚Äôt like this code, because I had to read it with my eyebrows. That is, I furrow my brow, and read slowly, and scowl at the code as I puzzle through it. This code is dense and tricky.
Is it Pythonic? I guess in the sense that it uses a number of Python-specific constructs and tools, yes. But not in the sense of Python code being clear and straightforward. It uses Python thoroughly, but misses ‚Ä¶
articles.title: On reading code with your eyebrows

articles.description:
Henrik Fricke:
Indiepen lets you embed HTML, CSS, and JS code examples on a website. We built it because we wanted to embed code examples on our  blog, but many existing solutions set cookies, have a ton of features or just come with a bad performance.
üòé No cookies, no tracking, no external requests
Congrats, Henrik, on shipping your first open source project! üëè
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Indiepen ‚Äì¬†a  privacy-friendly solution to present your code to people

articles.description:
It‚Äôs 22 months since I found myself frustrated with writing boilerplate instructions to install simple, but necessary software in every tutorial I wrote for clients and for my own open source work.
In this article post I‚Äôll walk you through the journey of the past two years from the initial creation, through to growing the community, getting the first sponsored app and what‚Äôs next. There will be code snippets, and technical details, but there should be something for everyone as we celebrate the two year ann‚Ä¶
articles.title: Building an open source marketplace for Kubernetes (2 years later)

articles.description:
Luis Villa of Tidelift joins the show to discuss GitHub Copilot and the implications of an AI pair programmer from a legal perspective.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make the ads disappear!
Sponsors
Retool ‚Äì¬†Retool is a low-code platform built specifically for developers that makes it fast and easy to build internal tools. Instead of building internal tools from scratch, the world‚Äôs best teams, from startups to Fortune 500s, are using Retool to ‚Ä¶
articles.title: JS Party 188: We ask a lawyer about GitHub Copilot

articles.description:
Fossil deliberately omits a ‚Äúrebase‚Äù command because the original designer of Fossil (and original author of this article) considers rebase to be an anti-pattern to be avoided. This article attempts to explain that point of view.
Read this article by SQLite/Fossil creator Richard Hipp to prep for next week‚Äôs episode of The Changelog. üòâ
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Rebase considered harmful

articles.description: This week Adam is joined by Eugenio Pace, co-founder and CEO of Auth0. Auth0 is a for developers, by developers identity, access, security, and authentication platform built for the cloud that secures billions of logins every year. Mid 2020 they raised $120 million at a $1.92 billion valuation after being told no several times. Then, earlier this year in March they announced they were being acquired by Okta for $6.5 billion, in a bold and future-thinking all stock deal. This episode is full of wisdom, inspi‚Ä¶
articles.title: Founders Talk 78: Leading Auth0 to a $6.5 billion acquisition

articles.description:
There‚Äôs a lot to love about online shopping: It‚Äôs fast, it‚Äôs easy and there are a ton of options to choose from. But there‚Äôs one obvious challenge ‚Äî you can‚Äôt try anything on. This is something Google product manager Debbie Biswas noticed, as a tech industry veteran and startup founder herself. ‚ÄúHistorically, the fashion industry only celebrates people of a certain size and skin color,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThis was something I wanted to change.‚Äù
Debbie grew up in India and moved to the U.S. after she graduated colle‚Ä¶
articles.title: This Googler‚Äôs team is making shopping more inclusive

articles.description:
‚ÄúFarmers feed the entire world ‚Äî so how might we support them to be resilient and build sustainable systems that also support global food security?‚Äù It‚Äôs a question that Diana Akrong found herself asking last year. Diana is a UX researcher based in Accra, Ghana, and the founding member of Google‚Äôs Accra UX team.
Across the world, her manager Dr. Courtney Heldreth, was equally interested in answering this question. Courtney is a social psychologist and a staff UX researcher based in Seattle, and both women w‚Ä¶
articles.title: These researchers are bringing AI to farmers

articles.description:
Before the pandemic, Alicia Chang was working on a new project. ‚ÄúI was experimenting with non-traditional ways to help teach Googlers the AI Principles,‚Äù she says. Alicia is a technical writer on the Engineering Education team focused on designing learning experiences to help Googlers learn about our AI Principles and how to apply them in their own work.
The challenge for Alicia would be how many people she needed to educate. ‚ÄúThere are so many people spread over different locations, time zones, countries!‚Äù‚Ä¶
articles.title: A crossword puzzle with a big purpose

articles.description: Here are six requirements that I have on a project for it to reach my gold approval for stellar docs. Then something about what I’ve done recently to further improve the docs for curl. Your docs belong in the code repository It needs to be next to the code so that authors and contributors can … Continue reading Making world-class docs takes effort →

articles.description: SVT is the Swedish national public television. They recently announced their new series Det svenska spelundret, which translated to “The Swedish game wonder” or something. It is a five episode documentary series about the history behind and the creation of the flourishing Swedish computer game industry. In Swedish and the only subtitles available are also … Continue reading Early me caught on TV →

articles.description: Over the last year, DeFi has grown significantly with billions of dollars of cryptocurrency locked into blockchain contracts. With this growth comes increased risk and DeFi funds are lucrative targets for malicious actors. Learn how a HackerOne hacker helps protect DeFi funds and mitigate this risk.
articles.title: Hacker-Powered Security and DeFi: How Human Intelligence Improves Cryptocurrency Security

articles.description: HackerOne announces new capabilities for AWS customers looking to improve security in their cloud applications. These include vulnerability pentests specific to AWS environments, an AWS Security Hub integration for fast, effective security actions, and AWS Certified hackers. AWS customers can now identify and fix vulnerabilities quickly and develop a better understanding of their cloud application security profile.
articles.title: HackerOne Announces Hacker-Powered Cloud Security Capabilities for AWS Customers

articles.description: HackerOne announced an integration with AWS Security Hub that exchanges vulnerability findings and streamlines workflows to accelerate security actions. The integration consolidates and routes vulnerability intelligence from HackerOne to AWS Security Hub, delivering greater visibility into crucial gaps that could lead to a cyberattack.
articles.title: How a New HackerOne Integration with AWS Security Hub Accelerates Vulnerability Remediation Time

articles.description: One of the primary missions of the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency (DCSA) is to provide critical technology protection to the Defense Industrial Base (DIB). Given the recent increase in cyber incidents affecting the DIB, DCSA views the DIB-VDP Pilot as a promising way to identify and stop attempts at stealing our Nation‚Äôs secrets.
articles.title: The DOD Improves Their Security Posture Through the DIB-VDP

articles.description: Hyatt‚Äôs three-year-old bug bounty program has reached a significant milestone: $500,000 in bounties paid to hackers. As the first organization in the hospitality industry to embrace hacker-powered security, Hyatt‚Äôs milestone today demonstrates its long-term commitment to setting the highest standard for cybersecurity.  We sat down with Robert Lowery, Senior Analyst at Hyatt, to learn more about the history of Hyatt‚Äôs bug bounty program and their most recent $500,000 milestone. Read on to see what Robert sha‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Last month we removed a bunch of content from MDN. MDN is 16 years old (and yes it can drink in some countries), all that time ago it was a great place for all of Mozilla to document all of their things. As MDN evolved and the web reference became our core content, other areas became less relevant to the overall site. We have ~11k active pages on MDN, so keeping them up to date is a big task and we feel our focus should be there.
The post Spring cleaning MDN: Part 2 appeared first on Mozilla Hacks - the Web‚Ä¶
articles.sourceTitle: Mozilla Hacks ‚Äì the Web developer blog
articles.title: Spring cleaning MDN: Part 2

articles.title: GitHub Enterprise Server 3.2 brings new color modes and added security capabilities

articles.description: We‚Äôre changing which keys are supported in SSH and removing unencrypted Git protocol. Only users connecting via SSH or git:// will be affected. If your Git remotes start with https://, nothing in this post will affect you. If you‚Äôre an SSH user, read on for the details and timeline.
articles.title: Improving Git protocol security on GitHub
